g.title:
<
4. Bd3
4. .. Nc6Black asks the question of how
white wants to defend the d pawn. White
should try to hinder the development of
black's white squared bishop. If 5. Nf3
played black's bishop development problems
are solved for him. So 5. Ne2 or5. c3is preferred. Black
continues with5. .. Nf6White has several options.
>
g.text: Black asks the question of how
white wants to defend the d pawn. White
should try to hinder the development of
black's white squared bishop. If 5. Nf3
are solved for him. So 5. Ne2 or

g.title:
<
6. h3
Again hinders development of black's light
squared bishop. 6. .. g6 can be played to
enable 7. .. Bf5 (or later). If bishop is
captured double pawns on the f file are fine,
specially when e6 is played.
>
g.text: Again hinders development of black's light
squared bishop. 6. .. g6 can be played to
enable 7. .. Bf5 (or later). If bishop is
captured double pawns on the f file are fine,

g.title:
<
4. Bd3
4. .. Nc6Black asks the question of how
white wants to defend the d pawn. White
should try to hinder the development of
black's white squared bishop. If 5. Nf3
played black's bishop development problems
are solved for him. So 5. Ne2 or5. c3is preferred. Black
continues with5. .. Nf6White has several options.
>-><
6. h3
Again hinders development of black's light
squared bishop. 6. .. g6 can be played to
enable 7. .. Bf5 (or later). If bishop is
captured double pawns on the f file are fine,
specially when e6 is played.
>

<
6. Bf4
mainline
White's immediate goal with this move to
control e5 and prevent black playing e5 at
some point.6. .. Bg4 7. Qb3to attack undefended
b7 pawn. (7. f3 can be played but block white
knight.)7. .. Qd2(7. .. e5 can be played
for very sharp lines).8. Nd2prepares Nf38.
.. e6 9. Nf3 Bd6(alternatively the white
bishop can be exchanged for the knight) If
white captures on d3 and black recaptures
with the queen white can take the b7 pawn.
But Rb8 is leads to good counter play. So
usually10.
0-0 0-0-0
White has the semiopen e file, black has the
semiopen c file. White can aim for the
control of e5.
>
g.text: White's immediate goal with this move to
control e5 and prevent black playing e5 at
b7 pawn. (7. f3 can be played but block white
bishop can be exchanged for the knight) If
white captures on d3 and black recaptures
with the queen white can take the b7 pawn.
But Rb8 is leads to good counter play. So
White has the semiopen e file, black has the
semiopen c file. White can aim for the

6. Bf4
mainline
White's immediate goal with this move to
control e5 and prevent black playing e5 at
some point.6. .. Bg4 7. Qb3to attack undefended
b7 pawn. (7. f3 can be played but block white

white captures on d3 and black recaptures
with the queen white can take the b7 pawn.
But Rb8 is leads to good counter play. So
usually10.
0-0 0-0-0
White has the semiopen e file, black has the
semiopen c file. White can aim for the
control of e5.
>

<
6. Nf3
Black can develop his light squared bishop.
>
g.text: Black can develop his light squared bishop.

should try to hinder the development of

<
The exchange variation
1. e4 c6 2. d4 d5 3. exd5 cxd5
>
g.text: 1. e4 c6 2. d4 d5 3. exd5 cxd5

g.title:
<
The exchange variation
1. e4 c6 2. d4 d5 3. exd5 cxd5
>-><

4. c4 -- The Panov-Botvinnik attack
panov-botvinnik attack
>
